critique: The document is an executive order from 1942 that temporarily modifies civil service rules to expedite the filling of positions during World War II. It prioritizes efficiency and speed in staffing federal agencies, potentially at the expense of strict adherence to competitive hiring processes. The order grants the Civil Service Commission broad authority to adjust recruitment and placement procedures. The temporary nature of the appointments and the focus on wartime needs suggest a pragmatic approach to governance during a national emergency.
